questions.question: Which automation principle keeps transfers from failing when paychecks arrive?
options: Scheduling transfers three days before payday
Running transfers the morning after each payday
Only transferring money manually on weekends
Waiting until bills are paid at month end
questions.explanation: Automating the sweep the morning after payday ensures cash is available and prevents the funds from being spent elsewhere first.

questions.question: When comparing high-yield savings accounts, which factor best protects your cash?
options: Unlimited ATM withdrawals
FDIC or NCUA insurance up to coverage limits
The bank's social media presence
Whether the bank offers credit cards
questions.explanation: Federal insurance ensures deposits are backed even if the institution fails, making it the most critical safety factor.

questions.question: You want to save $18,000 for graduate school tuition in 18 months. What monthly base contribution keeps you on target (ignoring interest)?
questions.explanation: $18,000 divided by 18 months equals $1,000 per month before accounting for interest.

questions.question: Round-up savings rules only work if you already transfer large lump sums each month.
questions.explanation: Micro-automations like round-ups accumulate savings from everyday spending and complement larger scheduled transfers.

questions.question: Which habit helps counter the instant gratification bias described in the Psychology of Saving lesson?
options: Reviewing your savings goals only at year-end
Pairing every transfer with a quick progress update or celebration
Waiting to save until you feel motivated
Keeping goals vague so they feel flexible
questions.explanation: Immediate positive reinforcement—like updating a tracker—gives your brain a reward right after saving, offsetting the bias.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of using goal-specific sub-accounts for major milestones?
options: Banks waive all account fees
It makes withdrawing money faster
Progress becomes visible and reduces temptation to spend the funds elsewhere
It increases your credit score
questions.explanation: Seeing each goal grow builds motivation and creates a psychological barrier against raiding the funds.

questions.question: Splitting emergency fund transfers into two smaller automations can help prevent overdrafts if pay dates shift.
questions.explanation: Breaking one large transfer into smaller rules gives you flexibility and reduces the risk of a single failed automation.

questions.question: Your HYSA balance is $12,000 earning 4.2% APY. Approximately how much interest will it earn over one year assuming the rate stays constant?
questions.explanation: 4.2% of $12,000 is about $504 in interest over a year before compounding adjustments.

questions.question: When building a savings dashboard, what should you review at the end of each month?
options: Only whether your checking account grew
Your goal balances, new contributions, and any timeline adjustments needed
How much friends saved so you can compare
Whether you earned credit card rewards
questions.explanation: Monthly reviews focus on progress toward each goal and help you recalibrate contribution amounts or deadlines.

questions.question: Which tactic accelerates compound growth without dramatically changing your budget?
options: Waiting to invest until rates are perfect
Increasing contributions by 1-2% whenever you receive a raise
Pausing contributions whenever expenses rise
Keeping all savings in a non-interest-bearing account
questions.explanation: Incremental increases tied to raises leverage income growth to amplify compounding while keeping spending stable.
